title: 110_s3359
content: The Act titled "American Shipping Reinvestment Act of 2008" repeals the qualified shipping investment withdrawal rules. The Act titled "American Shipping Reinvestment Act of 2008" repeals section 955 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, along with related conforming amendments and effective date provisions. The Act applies to taxable years of controlled foreign corporations and United States shareholders ending after the enactment date. SEC. 3. Temporary dividends received deduction for previously untaxed foreign base company shipping income. Section 965 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a temporary dividends received deduction for foreign base company shipping income. A deduction of 85 percent of cash distributions received by a United States shareholder from controlled foreign corporations is allowed, attributable to income derived before January 1, 2005. The amendment to Section 965 of the Internal Revenue Code allows a temporary dividends received deduction for foreign base company shipping income. A deduction of 85 percent of cash distributions received by a United States shareholder from controlled foreign corporations is permitted, attributable to income derived before January 1, 2005. The amount of dividends taken into account under this subsection is limited and a taxpayer election and designation are required for this purpose. The amendment to Section 965 of the Internal Revenue Code allows a temporary dividends received deduction for foreign base company shipping income. A United States shareholder may elect to apply paragraph (3) of section 959(c) before paragraphs (1) and (2) thereof, and designate the extent to which a cash distribution reduces a controlled foreign corporation's earnings and profits. The taxpayer may elect to apply this subsection to their last taxable year. The taxpayer may elect to apply the amendment to Section 965 of the Internal Revenue Code to their last taxable year before the enactment date. This election must be made before the due date for filing the tax return. Failure to maintain employment levels may result in a reduction in benefits during the specified period after receiving a distribution. If the taxpayer does not maintain an average employment level equal to their prior average, they may have to include an additional amount in their income. The prior average employment is calculated based on the average number of employees over the 24 months before the specified period. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending on or after the date of the enactment of this Act, including aggregation rules for determining average employment levels within a controlled group.
